subject: Bowling for Art
event: The local newspapers have all broken the story, so I might as well acknowledge it here as well. Yeah, I bought a bowling alley. Except... well... not really.  I bought the former Silva Lanes property on Rufina Circle, a block off Cerrillos Road in south Santa Fe.  But there hasn't been any bowling there since 2009, when Silva Lanes went bankrupt.  And, indeed, all the lanes and interior furnishings were ripped out several years ago by a previous "buyer" who then failed to follow through with the purchase.  So essentially I bought a huge empty derelict building (some 33,000 square feet) and a big parking lot. I also have acquired a very tall bowling-pin-shaped sign, for what it's worth (not much). Sad to say (for bowling fans), I am not planning to bring bowling back to Santa Fe.  (Some other folks are doing that, supposedly, with brand new lanes in the Railyard District a few blocks from the Cocteau).  Nor will I be using the space for a karaoke bar.  The previous owner tried that too. The building, instead, will be used for art... not a traditional gallery, now, but a very exciting and innovative interactive art space.   The exhibits will be designed and installed by Meow Wolf, a collective of forty-odd (some very odd) artists here in Santa Fe who have been doing some amazing things over the past decade, but have never had a permanent home before. Meow Wolf will be announcing their plans in the next month.  Till then, here are some stories:  http://www.sfreporter.com/santafe/article-9749-meow-wolf-to-take-over-old-silva-lanes.html  http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/business/martin-meow-wolf-join-to-make-silva-lanes-an-art/article_a2c265d9-73c9-5059-be92-260fadeb064e.html   http://www.abqjournal.com/522152/news/old-bowling-alley-on-its-way-to-an-artistic-transformation.html And check out the Meow Wolf home page, for a better idea of the kind of stuff they do.  http://meowwolf.com/ I think this should be very exciting, and real boost to local tourism, the arts scene, something kids of all ages will enjoy.  But that's really up to Meow Wolf.  My phone has been ringing off the hook with calls from people wanting comments about this, but I'm not the guy to talk to.  Bottom line, I am just the landlord.  The dream, the vision, and the hard work all belong to Meow Wolf. But it should be cool. And yes, we're going to keep the big bowling pin.  I insisted.

props.taglist: artwork, everyday life, santa fe. meow wolf

comments.article: Art is subjective and to me that big bowling pin is a wonderful piece of art. Kudos on keeping it!
comments.subject: It's subjective

comments.article: And once a year, the GRRM Convention :D

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: horns
comments.article: That is so freakin' cool, George. I can't wait to come out and see it once the collective is in residence!
Seconded.

"I am not planning to bring bowling back to Santa Fe."

Well, there could be bowling based art exhibits, given that this place will be a "a very exciting and innovative interactive art space."
That's really cool. You're doing an amazing role like the old patrons of renaissance. It is really cool to know you're so engaged in your community.
Good on you, sir! If I was filthy rich, I would love to do something like this in my home city.
YAY ART!
on the bowling pin, not sure if very artistic but I wouldn't take the titan of braavos down if ever get to conquer braavos
Great to see you're using some of the money you've earned (which you richly deserve every penny of) for arts patronage - it's really inspiring. Kudos!

New reason to visit Santa Fe this summer!

Thank you for facilitating such an interesting artistic concept. His projects are fantastic. I hope to attend a monster battle someday :) Keep us posted on the developments from Meow!
comments.subject: Awesome!

comments.upictitle: Jen: Batman drinking coffee by the_dark_cat
comments.article: I love this idea!

DEFINITELY keep the big bowling pin! And restore the neon, if possible -- that makes it a work of art all by itself!

Wonderful building. That's exactly the sort of thing I'd love to be able to do. Hope we get a chance to get back up to Santa Fe sometime to check this out.
I seriously want to be you when I grow up. Never mind that I'm 42. Between your writing, the cinema, and the art space you're doing a lot of cool stuff!
So cooooool!! Great!
*beams idiotically* I am so pleased that you are using your powers for good!
You rock, sir. You rock like a very rocky thing indeed.

I like this idea.  Talk about recycling and utilizing a building!!  And the big bowling pin?  Here in Jacksonville we used to have a gooney golf course out on one of the main roads leading to the beach.  They had a T-Rex statue.  When the golf course folded and new owners bought the area they left the dinosaur statue.  It's still there, more than 50 years later and it's considered a local landmark.  I hope your bowling pin lasts as long and becomes as well loved.  (But that the art gallery lasts a lot longer than the gooney golf course!)
You should have kept it a bowling alley and call it Clegane Bowling

Well done, George!

#Nous sommes tous Charlie

George, I have to tell you- I have never in my life had any drive to visit Santa Fe. However, reading your Not A Blog over the last few years is seriously making me consider it!

Between the theatre and the art space, I'm starting to think it might make a neat mini-vacation! Top this stuff off with geeky bar (or possibly a geeky football bar, which would be amazing) and I might never leave!

Thanks for using your fame/money/time to invest in more art, and bring it back to the community. I think that's awesome.

Cool. I didn't know that Santa Fe used to have a Pueblo Revival bowling alley! Of course, I should have suspected that it would be since many parts of Santa Fe buildings are required to be either Pueblo Revival or Territorial in style.

I'll have to point out that this won't be the only bowling pin sign left in New Mexico on something that isn't a bowling alley anymore. While the bowling alley that used to be located on the northeast corner of Menaul and San Pedro in Albuquerque is gone (building and all) replaced by a Staples and a Guitar Center, the sign for the bowling alley remains. (This one is a neon bowling pin and ball design). I confirmed this during my visit to Albuquerque last week, so the sign was there as recently as a week ago.

Dear Mr. Martin,

Huge fan! Love your work. Glad to see you're busily enjoying life in Santa Fe. Can't wait 'till April!

About the art building, sounds like a very cool project and a real asset to the community.

Best regards,
Matt
